facts.text: Appellant joined Indian Police Service on October 3, 1952 as a result of competitive examination held in 1951, posted in State of Punjab, confirmed on November 30, 1953.

Punjab has 57 senior posts in Indian Police Service, out of which some filled by promotion per r.9 IPS Recruitment Rules 1954; number of junior posts laid down in IPS Fixation of Cadre Strength Regulations 1955.

Posts of Superintendents of Police are in senior time-scale; initial pay of direct recruit fixed at minimum of junior time-scale; on appointment to senior time-scale post, pay fixed at corresponding stage per Schedule I of IPS Pay Rules 1954.
On January 27, 1958, appellant promoted to officiate in senior time-scale, posted as Additional Superintendent of Police, Ferozepore vice Shri Siasat Singh on leave; pay fixed at Rs. 600.
On April 19, 1958, appellant transferred and posted as Additional Superintendent of Police, Punjab Armed Police, Ferozepore, carrying special pay of Rs. 100 per month.
Appellant earned increment on October 3, 1958, basic pay raised from Rs. 600 to Rs. 640 per month.
On July 18, 1958, appellant served with charge sheet, submitted reply which did not satisfy Government; enquiry ordered but before starting, reverted.
On November 3, 1958, appellant reverted to substantive rank of Assistant Superintendent of Police (junior scale), posted at Amritsar from date relieved.
Officers junior to appellant in IPS cadre of Punjab State continued officiating in senior scale when appellant reverted.
Appellant filed writ petition in Punjab High Court challenging reversion; dismissed as premature since appeal to Government of India pending.
Government of India dismissed appellant's appeal on May 8, 1959.
Appellant filed second writ petition (Civil Writ No. 752/1959) in Punjab High Court; heard by Khosla C.J. and Dulat J., dismissed on January 20, 1961.
Supreme Court granted special leave; appeal heard.
From personal file: Note dated October 6, 1958 by Senior Superintendent suggesting shift from Ferozepore as enquiry into conduct might take long.
Note suggesting revert and proceed with enquiry on charge of not carrying out orders; appellant not ripe/fit for SP duties; revert on unsatisfactory record.
Appellant had brilliant academic career, no adverse remarks communicated, recommended for Indian Police Medal for gallantry a month before reversion, given increment.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellant had a right to be promoted to a post in senior scale as and when vacancy arises (except promotion quota) if no senior available.
Whether order of reversion dated November 3, 1958 amounts to reduction in rank within Art. 311(2) Constitution due to forfeiture of right.
Whether reversion involved penal consequences (loss of pay, seniority, future promotion) per Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India, thus punishment requiring Art. 311 compliance.
Whether reversion was mala fide, improper, violating Arts. 14 and 16 Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Under relevant rules, member of IPS entitled as of right to promotion to senior scale vacancy (except promotion quota) when no senior available; juniors officiating when reverted, so reversion = reduction in rank u/Art. 311(2), no show cause given.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: IPS Regulation of Seniority Rules 1954 r.6; Art. 311(2) Constitution

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if no right, reversion penal per Dhingra: loss of pay, seniority, future promotion chances.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India (1958 SCR 828)

petitioner_arguments.text: Reversion mala fide, improper, against Arts. 14, 16.

respondent_arguments.text: No absolute right to senior scale vacancy; appointment per r.4(2) IPS Pay Rules 1954 involves selection process, not automatic.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: IPS Pay Rules 1954 r.4(2); IPS Cadre Rules 1954

respondent_arguments.text: Reversion not punishment/penalty but administrative: appellant not fit/ripe for SP duties after trial; unrelated to departmental enquiry; covered by Expl.4 to r.3 AIS Discipline & Appeal Rules 1955.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: All India Services (Discipline and Appeal) Rules 1955 r.3 Expl.4

respondent_arguments.text: No violation of Art. 311(2); not mala fide or violating Arts.14/16.

court_reasoning.text: No automatic right to senior scale post; appointment required per r.4(2), r.8 IPS Pay Rules 1954; Expl.4 AISDAR r.3 negatives right to officiate higher post merely by seniority.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Junior to senior scale not automatic; involves appointment by authority.

court_reasoning.text: Though no right to post, reversion visited penal consequences: loss of pay (beyond inevitable), loss of seniority, postponement of promotion; file shows punitive intent (unsatisfactory conduct, immature, shift pending enquiry).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Substance over form; per Dhingra test 2, penal consequences indicate punishment.

court_reasoning.text: No opportunity to show cause against proposed action; violates Art. 311(2).
Mudholkar J.: IPS has one cadre; junior scale officer has right to senior scale post by seniority (not selection like promotions from State service); reversion punitive/mala fide per file notes.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Transition from junior to senior by seniority, not selection; file shows devious method to avoid enquiry/suspension.

holdings.text: No right to automatic promotion to senior scale post.
Reversion order dated November 3, 1958 was by way of punishment involving penal consequences, violating Art. 311(2) for lack of opportunity to show cause.
Reversion tantamount to reduction in rank requiring Art.311 compliance.

precedents_cited.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Test for when reversion/reduction is punishment: right to post or penal consequences (forfeiture pay/allowances, loss seniority, stoppage future promotion).

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Protection against reduction in rank without opportunity; equality; writ jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: All India Services Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to make rules for IPS recruitment, conditions of service, pay, cadre, discipline.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Police Service (Pay) Rules, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Time-scales (junior/senior); fixation of pay on appointment to senior scale post; pay for Schedule III posts requires appointment.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Police Service (Cadre) Rules, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Cadre constitution, strength, filling by cadre officers.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Police Service (Recruitment) Rules, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Methods: competitive exam, promotion (25% senior posts).

statutes_cited.name: Indian Police Service (Fixation of Cadre Strength) Regulations, 1955
Indian Police Service (Regulation of Seniority) Rules, 1954
All India Services (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Penalties including reduction in rank; reversion after trial/admin reasons not penalty.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; order of reversion dated November 3, 1958 quashed as violative of Art. 311(2) Constitution being punishment without opportunity to show cause; appellant entitled to costs of Supreme Court and High Court.
outcome.relief_granted: Quashing of reversion order; restoration implied to prior position with costs.
outcome.costs: Appellant entitled to costs of this Court and the High Court.

key_quotes.text: "The real test for determining whether the reduction in such cases is or is not by way of punishment is to find out if the order for the reduction also visits the servant with any penal consequences."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Dhingra case, applied to find penal consequences in reversion.

key_quotes.text: "We have therefore come to the conclusion that the first contention urged on behalf of the appellant that he has a right to go automatically into the senior scale is not correct and cannot be upheld."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects automatic right to senior scale.

key_quotes.text: "Our conclusion is that in the present case the appellant was reverted by way of punishment, but he was given no opportunity of showing cause against the action proposed to be taken against him."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A perusal of the file thus shows that instead of suspending the appellant during the pendency of the enquiry against him... resort was had to his reversion on the vague grounds that he was a problem child and an immature person."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Mudholkar J. on mala fide nature from file notes.
